panels.description:
RSS — physical RAM used by the process (includes heap, stack, code, and mapped files).  

Virtual — Total virtual memory reserved by the process (includes all memory mappings, not all in RAM).  

Shared — File-backed memory (like shared libraries) currently loaded in RAM, excludes heap.
panels.title: Process Memory

panels.description:
Total amount of CPU timenthe Go runtime has spent scavenging unused memory pages back to the operating system.

The scavenger runs in the background to return unused heap memory to the OS.

It helps reduce the memory footprint of your app, especially for long-lived processes with fluctuating memory usage.
panels.title: Memory Scavenging

panels.description: These are part of Pressure Stall Information (PSI) — showing how long your process was waiting or stalled due to lack of CPU, I/O, or memory.
panels.title: Pressure

panels.description: Cumulative total time that goroutines in a Go application have spent waiting to acquire a locked mutex.
panels.title: Mutex Wait

panels.description:
User — time spent in user space (your Go code).  
Kernel — time spent in kernel/system calls (e.g., I/O, syscalls).
panels.title: CPU Time

panels.description: Go scheduler latency refers to the delay a goroutine experiences between becoming ready to run and actually being scheduled and executed by the Go runtime on an operating system thread.
panels.title: Go Scheduler Latency

panels.description: Duration of "Stop-the-World" (STW) pauses caused by the GC.
panels.title: GC STW Duration

panels.description: Heap size in bytes at which the next GC will trigger.
panels.title: GC Trigger
